11. The supreme good was a subject of anxious disputa, and even contentiori, among the ancient philosophers; yet none of them, except Plato, ackuowledged the chief good of man to consist in his union with God. But of the nature of thie union he had not even the smallest idea; end no wonder, for he was totally uninformed respecting the sacred bond of it. We know what is the only and perfect happiness even in this earthly pilgrimage; but it daily inflames our hearts with in· creasing desires after it, till we shall be satisfied with its full fruition. Therefore l have observed that the advantage of Christ’s benefits is solely enjoyed by those who elevate their minds to the resurrection. Thus Paul also sets before believers this object, towards which he tells us he directs all his own efforts, forgetting every thing else, “ if by any means he may attain unto it.’' (a) And it behoves us to prese forward to the same point with ‘the greater alacrity, lest, if this world engross our attention, we should be grievously punished for our sloth.
